w:r.w:t: NOT TO BE ISSUED TO STUDENTS
MEM10119 Certificate I in Engineering & Statement of Attainment towards MEM20422 Certificate II in Engineering Pathways
MEM12024 Perform computations & MEM16008 Interact with computer technology & MEM07032 Use workshop machines for basic operations
List any pre-requisite or co-requisite units of competency:
MEM13015 Work safely and effectively in manufacturing and engineering & MEM16006 Organise and communicate information & MEM11011 Undertake manual handling & MEM18001 Use hand tools
MEM10119 Certificate I in Engineering & Statement of Attainment towards MEM20422 Certificate II in Engineering Pathways

The student is to be assessed on their ability to demonstrate that they can:

w:tblCaption.w:val: Table outlining Cluster name and competencies to be covered.

w:r.w:t: The sections are broken down into the following:
Each section will be reported as Satisfactory (S) or Not Yet Satisfactory (NYS). When all components of a task are completed satisfactorily the student outcome for the unit will be Competent.
These can be performed either in an industry workplace or a simulated industry environment.
The school will provide safe and well-maintained facilities, equipment, tools and materials as required for each individual unit of competency in order to allow the assessment to be undertaken

All students must be provided the opportunity to access and participate in the learning and assessment process. Reasonable adjustment must be discussed with individual students prior to assessment. Reasonable adjustments are implemented to provide equitable access for students while maintaining the integrity of the qualification and industry outcome. All reasonable adjustments must be documented on the student assessment copy
Students must complete all components of the assessment to a satisfactory level to be deemed as competent for a unit of competency.
MEM07032 Use workshop machines for basic operations
MEM07032 Use workshop machines for basic operations
Each student has 2 hours to complete this section.
The teacher ensures the student has access to the written questions.
Ensure the student is ready and willing to undertake the assessment.
Ensure the student has access to any relevant resources listed.

If the student does not answer a question in full, the teacher may ask the student to provide more information to be deemed satisfactory. If this is required, the teacher must document the question they ask the student and document the response against the question requiring further information.
Ensure all responses are a student’s own work.

After completion, the teacher will hold a debrief (feedback) session with the student. The student will share any insights or lessons they have gained and discuss any takeaways that could be applied to real-life situations.
Knowledge as required by the unit of competence through all written activities.
safe work practices and procedures and use of personal protective equipment (PPE)
cutting tool sharpening methods and techniques
safe operation of tool sharpening equipment and consequences of incorrect sharpening
machine set-up and consequences of incorrect speeds and feeds
units of measurement, tool geometry & numerical operations required for basic machining operations
formulae applicable to perimeter, area & volume of simple geometric shapes & the reasons for using dimensions with the same units
techniques & procedures for rounding off figures when estimating approximate answers
features and use of mixed numbers, decimals, fractions and whole numbers
procedures for carrying out calculations involving fractions and using each of the four basic rules of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division
concept of percentage and procedures to be followed in converting a decimal and fraction to a percentage
concepts and calculations of ratio and proportion
scales applicable to the axes of the graphs or charts
types of charts and/or graphs used in the individual’s field of work
upper and lower limits of acceptability applicable to data entered on a graph or chart
trends indicated by the graphs or charts drawn
trends indicated by the slope or gradient of a graph
action to be taken when given trends occur or set limits are approached on graphs or charts
procedures for drawing ‘lines of best fit’
functions and capabilities of computing technology used in the workplace
use and features of data outputs.
Each student must submit the following evidence:
Each student will be provided with the following resources to complete the assessment task.
What should you do if you identify a hazard in your work area?
Report it to the appropriate work safe authority in your region after isolating it in order to meet legislative requirements
Assess the level of risk, control what can be controlled immediately and report to the appropriate person in the business for further action
Report it to the supervisor and leave it to them to manage
Reading and following Safe Operating Procedures (SOP) of each machine
Using only the hand tools that are in your work area
Tying back loose hair and clothing
What PPE is commonly used when machining?
How could Metal Chips be safely removed from a lathe or mill?
Flick away quickly whilst machine is running.
Stop machine and brush chips away
Brush chips whilst machine is slowing down
Blow chips away with an air compressor
Identify the correct procedure order for sharpening a high-speed steel lathe bit
When sharpening a lathe tool on a pedestal grinder, how would you prevent overheating and discoloration to the end of the tool?
Use a coarse wheel for grinding
Gently press the tool against the wheel rather than forcing it against the wheel
Dip the tool in coolant regularly when grinding
Grind in short fast bursts to allow the tool to cool down
Units of measurement most often used when machining are
Numerical operations required when machining include
All of these are numerical operations required when machining
Insert words from the word bank to correctly label the lathe cutting tool

w:r.w:t: Consequences of incorrect tool sharpening include
is machined above centreline it will not contact material.
Grinding the bevel of a tool at the wrong angle risks making the edge too thin and delicate
Identify the correct procedure order for safely using a pedestal grinder to sharpen a high speed steel lathe tool
Adjust tool rest if required (within 1.5-2mm of wheel)
Position tool and start the grinder
Check grinding wheel and make sure guards are in place
Identify the correct procedure order for setting up a lathe to face a steel rod
Insert the work piece into chuck and tighten chuck jaws
Identify and select the correct tool required for the job
Adjust the tool position, tool height and secure in tool post
Identify the correct speed and feed settings for the task you are undertaking
Ensure the Chuck Key is removed and step out of the line of the spinning chuck before turning the lathe on
Identify the correct procedure order for setting up a milling machine to cut a slot
Secure work piece in milling machine vice.
Identify and choose the correct milling cutter for task and install
Identify and adjust to correct cutting depth
Identify the correct speed and feed settings for the task you are undertaking
Move and align material with cutter
What would happen if a drill bit is used with excessive RPM or feed speed?
Overheat the drill bit and work harden work piece
Produces a polished surface on work piece
Some round bar (stock) has been correctly secured in a lathe
, identify the procedure order of operations to face off the stock
Clamp the cutting tool in the tool post
and use shims to adjust until the cutting tip is
to the centre of the round bar
move the cutting tool with the
post so that the tip of the cutting tool will meet the end of the
lowly advance the cross feed handwheel to move the tool
end of the round bar as
While the lathe is off, use
move the cutting tool tip until it touches the face of the round bar
and then remove the cutting tip from the round bar face before starting the lathe
has been correctly secured in a
, identify the procedure order of operations to
Zero the axis’ on your RDO
Position the cutter at the starting point of the slot. Use the milling machine's controls to align the cutter with the workpiece accurately.
Choose an appropriate slotting cutter for cutting the desired slot size and depth in the steel
Insert the cutter into the chuck and tighten.
Depending on the slot's depth and width, you may need to cut in multiple passes. Incrementally lower the cutter after each pass until you achieve the desired slot dimensions.
Square material is best held in which chuck
What is the purpose of the slots that are machined into the table of a mill?
To allow chip to fall through
To allow vices and other clamping devises to be bolted to the table
To allow drill bits to pass through after it goes through the material
To keep it cool by allowing air to pass through it during operations
What determines the speed of the machine when selecting the max rpm for a milling operation?
Material being machined, size of the cutter, what the cutter is made of
What the cutter is made of, The size of the machine, Machine SOP’s
Capability of machine, Materials being machined, Size of cutter
Operator training, Materials being machined, Type of cutter
Which of the following statements are NOT correct in relation to cutting fluid?
Poor finish on materials when using the lathe or milling machine may be a result of
Identifying and selecting the correct cutter for the task
on Evidence Central will be dynamic
will differ to the example answers provided below.
During calculations, why it is important to use dimensions with the same units?
Using different units will result in calculation errors
It keeps working out tidy on the page
Using units relevant to industry will assist with reading plans and ordering materials
The code of conduct requires worker to do this
You have been asked to measure and conduct various tasks on a round steel pipe with the following dimensions – internal diameter = 150mm and length = 10m.
Use this scenario to answer Question
Calculate the internal circumference (in mm) of the round steel pipe. (
) of the round steel pipe (to 2 decimal places). (
You have been asked to conduct various tasks on a shipping container with the following dimensions – length = 10m, width = 5m and height = 4m.
Use this scenario to answer Question
Calculate the total length (in metres) of steel angle required to cover all external edges of the shipping container.
of Colourbond sheeting required to line all sides of the shipping container.
What percentage of the shipping container would be filled if 100
A metal fabricator must cut a section of 5.22m RHS into 5 even parts. Use this scenario to answer Question
Estimate the length of each part to the nearest metre
Rounding to 2 decimal places, what is the length of each part?
When machining we use decimals, fractions and whole numbers. Match the number type to its features and purpose when machining,
Are essential in metal machining for material quantities
rovides precise measurements, dimensions, tolerances. Vernier callipers and machine DRO use this number type to improve accuracy and efficiency when machining
Imperial type of measurement that measures parts of a whole number.
to determine thread cutting settings on a lathe.
Complete the table on fractions, decimals, equivalent fractions and percentage.
The repeated addition of groups of equal value
A relationship between two numbers, that expresses one number as a fraction of the other
When you take one number away from another
An equation in which two ratios are set to equal each other
The repeated addition of groups of equal value
two numbers, that expresses one number as a fraction of the other
When you take one number away from another
An equation in which two ratios are set to equal each other
A metal fabricator has been asked to fillet weld on 160mm of a 200mm section of steel.
What fraction of the steel section will they be welding on?
Computing technology and software provides us with many functions and capabilities that are helpful when machining.
Match the computing technology or software to its purpose when machining,
Lathe and milling machine digital read out

Controls CNC operated machines, automates machining operations, achieves precision and efficiency, supports complex geometries, optimises cutting strategies, integrates with CAD/CAM systems and enable customisation
Helps guide and position cutting tools to creates more accurate products and increases efficiency by reducing manual measurement
It provides a versatile and powerful platform for data organisation, analysis, calculation, reporting. Can be used to chart data.
Provides users with a versatile platform for communication, information access and production. Required to use software such as Microsoft Excel.
Computing technology and software provides us with important data outputs that are helpful when machining.
Match the data output to its features and purpose when machining,
Estimates trend identification, correlation assessment, prediction, modelling relationships, data interpretation and visual communication of data patterns
machining it is to enhance precision, accuracy, efficiency and control
Is a versatile tool for data visualisation and analysis, providing a clear to understand trends, relationships, changes and patterns in machining data
Types of charts and/or graphs are used when machining metal. Match the graph or chart and to its purpose during machining,
Visually represents the relationship between two things, for example, drill speeds and drill bit diameters
way of decoding sheet metal thickness and weight which influences machine settings and operations
Provides information & guidance for selecting, using and using thread cutting taps, drill sizes and thread specifications
Table of numbers that indicates speed and feed rates for different drill bits and metal material types
The x and y axes scales, within graphs, we may use when machining could include
Useful graph trends, we may use when machining could include
How aesthetically pleasing the job will look when it’s completed.
Faster or slower tool feed rate
Use this graph information to answer question

w:r.w:t: The trends indicated by the slope/gradient of this line graph would be
Spindle speed RPM must increase when using a smaller drill bit diameter
Spindle speed RPM must decrease when using a smaller drill bit diameter
Spindle speed RPM must decrease when using a larger drill bit diameter
Spindle speed RPM must increase when using a larger drill bit diameter
What spindle speed RPM should be used for a drill bit 6mm in diameter
Estimate the spindle speed RPM used for a drill bit 14mm in diameter
If a drill bit 14mm in diameter is required for the task you should
Use the estimate spindle speed RPM you established via sight
Produce an entirely new graph with the 14mm data
Use the “lines of best fit” method
Discuss with the supervisor the job requirements outside of the information you have been provided
Data within a chart has upper and lower limits. Match the chart limit statement to an explanation of why it is occurring,
Line does not go lower than 4 (mm) on the x axis (diameter (mm) of drill bit)
The data entered for this graph did not include spindle speeds below 500 RPM. This machine may not produce spindle speeds below 500RPM.
Line does not go higher than 2500 RPM on the y axis (spindle speed RPM)
The data entered for this graph did not include spindle speeds above 2500 RPM. This machine may not produce spindle speeds above 2500RPM.
Line does not go higher than 12 (mm) on the x axis (diameter (mm) of drill bit)
The data entered for this graph did not include drill bits less then 4mm in diameter. Drill bits less then 4mm in diameter may not suit the task.
Line does not go lower than 500 RPM on the y axis (spindle speed RPM)
The data entered for this graph did not include drill bits more then 12mm in diameter. Drill bits more then 12mm in diameter may not suit the task.
The “Lines of best fit” procedure can be used to estimate the relationship between 2 variables. Match the ‘lines of best fit” picture to its procedure order number and description,

Section 2 Part B – Computer Aided Drawing (CAD)
Your teacher will provide you with a set of project plans
Develop a 3D model of ONE project (identified by your trainer) using an appropriate CAD program such as Fusion, Autodesk Inventor or Google Sketchup.

Produce a pictorial view of the project and 3 orthographic views showing overall dimensions of the project and laid out according to AS1100 standards. The pictorial view may be rendered by the software. Ensure your title block is completed.
Identify/locate the help menu or CAD program tutorial and follow as required
Ensure the item is drawn using the appropriate dimensions and units
Save the file and capture a screen shot of the 3D model
Submit to your assessor via email
Paste your completed work below where indicated
Log off and shut down the computer
Consult with your teacher and/or use information sources for assistance when required

w:r.w:t: Develop a computer-generated material list using a spread-sheeting program such as Microsoft Excel for ONE project (identified by your trainer). The
list must include the following and look like the example below.
Each part of the project listed and the dimensions of the material used
A formula to calculate the total length of material for each part (Length x Quantity)
graph showing the total cost of producing each item.
Paste your computer-generated material list using a spread-sheeting program
pie graph showing the total cost of producing each item

After completion, the teacher will hold a debrief (feedback) session with the student. The student will share any insights or lessons they have gained and discuss any takeaways that could be applied to real-life situations.
Each student will be provided with the following resources to complete the assessment task.
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and relevant mandatory signage
Selected machinery (eg lathe and/or milling machine) and consumables
Selected machinery tools and equipment (eg cutters, drill bits knurling tool)
Instructions on the Performance Criteria that need to be achieved and observed by the assessor
For students deemed Not Yet Satisfactory for a task, an opportunity will be provided by the assessor to reattempt the task where possible.
Due to the cost of material and assessment restraints, students can have a maximum of 3 attempts for this assessment.
MEM07032 Use workshop machines for basic operations
machining activities, the student must follow workplace and manufacturer procedures to demonstrate planning and preparing, including:
Identifying and interpreting projects and specifications
appropriate machine and tools to meet work requirements
Installing tools in the selected machines
Setting and adjusting the machine guards
materials using clamping device appropriate to the material
During the associated task, if the student was viewed undertaking the Observable Criteria, record the date they were Satisfactory (S) or Not Yet Satisfactory (NYS) in the boxes provided.
